div.p: § 352. By far the greater part of the word-forming elements, used in the parent language, were no longer felt as such in Gothic. In this chapter we shall chiefly confine ourselves to those word-forming elements which remained productive, such as prefixes and suffixes.
§ 354. Derivative nouns are formed in a great variety of ways:—

item.p: 4. By means of various prefixes. Some of the forms given as prefixes below are in reality independent words forming the first element of compounds. They have been included among the real prefixes for purely practical purposes. It should be noted that the examples given below include both nouns and adjectives:—

div.p: § 356. afar- (O.Icel. afar-, OHG. avar-, a deriv. of Indg. *ápo + the comparative suffix -er-os, after, cp. Skr. áparas, the latter; adv. aparám, later), as afar-dags, the next day; afar-sabbatus, the first day after the Sabbath.
§ 359. at- (O.Icel. OS. at-, OE. æt-, OHG. aȥ-, at, to, Lat. ad, to), only in at-aþni, year; at-witáins, observation.
§ 361. dis- (probably borrowed from Lat. dis-, apart, asunder), only in dis-taheins, dispersion; dis-wiss, dissolution.
§ 362. faír- (OHG. fir-, far-, NHG. Ver-, Skr. pári, Gr. πέρι, περί, around, Lat. per, through), only in faír-weitl, spectacle.
§ 366. fram- (O.Icel. OE. OS. OHG. fram-, from), as fram-aldrs, very old; fram-gāhts, progress.
§ 368. hindar- (OE. hinder, OHG. hintar, behind), only in hinder-weis, deceitful; hindar-weisei, deceitfulness.
§ 369. id- (OE. ed-, OHG. ita-, it-, back, again, re-), only in idweit (OE. edwīt, OHG. ita-wīȥ, it-wīȥ), reproach.
§ 371. inna- (O.Icel. OE. inne, OHG. inna, within), only in inna-kunds, of the same household.
§ 378. wiþra- (OE. wiþer, OHG. widar, against), only in wiþra-waírþs, opposite.

§ 389.
In compound nouns formed by composition the second element is always a noun, but the first element may be a noun, adjective, or a particle.
The declension and gender of compound nouns are determined by the final element.
þiuþi-qiss instead of *þiuþa-qiss, blessing.

§ 399.
From a morphological point of view, all verbs may be divided into two great classes: simple and compound.
Simple verbs are sub-divided into primary and denominative verbs.
To the former sub-division belong the strong verbs and a certain number of weak verbs, and to the latter the denominative verbs.
The simple primary verbs are here left out of further consideration, as their formation belongs to the wider field of comparative grammar.
Compound verbs are of various kinds:
(1) those formed from simple verbs by means of separable or inseparable particles,
(2) those formed from nouns and adjectives with verbal prefixes or suffixes.

§ 401.
Compound verbs are formed from simple verbs, nouns, and adjectives, by means of various prefixes.
See below.
On the accentuation of the prefixes in verbs see §§ 33–4.
